Sentences: Good afternoon.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: I am pleased to join you for the first of my post-FOMC press conferences.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Like Chairman Bernanke before me, I appreciate the opportunity these press conferences afford to explain the decisions of the FOMC and respond to your questions.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: The Federal Open Market Committee concluded a two-day meeting earlier today.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: As you already know from our statement, the Committee decided to make another modest reduction in the pace of its purchases of longer-term securities.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: The Committee also updated its guidance regarding the likely future path of the short-term interest rates.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: As I’ll explain more fully in a moment, this change in our guidance does not indicate any change in the Committee’s policy intentions as set forth in its recent statements; rather, the change is meant to clarify how the Committee anticipates policy evolving after the unemployment rate declines below 6½ percent.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Let me explain the economic outlook that underlies these actions.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Despite some softer recent data, the FOMC’s outlook for continued progress toward our goals of maximum employment and inflation returning to 2 percent remains broadly unchanged.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Unusually harsh weather in January and February has made assessing the underlying strength of the economy especially challenging.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Broadly speaking, however, the spending and production data, while somewhat weaker than we had expected in January, are roughly in line with our expectations as of December, the last time Committee participants submitted economic projections.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: In contrast, labor market conditions have continued to improve.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: The unemployment rate, at 6.7 percent, is three-tenths lower than the data available at the time of the December meeting.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Further, broader measures of unemployment—such as the U-6 measure, which includes marginally attached workers and those working part time but preferring full-time  force participation has ticked up.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: While the Committee continues to monitor developments in global financial markets carefully, financial conditions remain broadly consistent with the FOMC’s objectives.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: In sum, the FOMC continues to see sufficient underlying strength in the economy to support ongoing improvement in the labor market.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Inflation has continued to run below the Committee’s 2 percent objective.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Given that longer-term inflation expectations appear to be well anchored, and in light of the ongoing recovery in the United States and in many economies around the world, the FOMC continues to expect inflation to move gradually back toward its objective.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: The Committee is mindful that inflation running persistently below its objective could pose risks to economic performance.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: The Committee also recognizes, however, that policy actions tend to exert pressure on inflation that is manifest only gradually over time.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: The FOMC will continue assessing incoming data carefully to ensure that policy is consistent with attaining the FOMC’s longer-run objectives of maximum employment and inflation of 2 percent.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: This outlook is reflected in the individual economic projections submitted in conjunction with this meeting by the 16 FOMC participants—4 Board members and 12 Reserve Bank presidents.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: As always, each participant’s projections are conditioned on his or her own view of appropriate monetary policy.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: The central tendency of the unemployment rate projections has shifted down by about two-tenths since December and now stands at between 6.1 and 6.3 percent at the end of this year.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: The unemployment rate is projected to reach its longer-run normal level by the end of 2016.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: The central tendency of the projections for real GDP growth stands at 2.8 to 3 percent for 2014 and remains somewhat above that of the estimates of longer-run normal growth through 2016.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Meanwhile, as I noted, FOMC participants continue to see inflation  tendency of the inflation projections is 1.5 to 1.6 percent in 2014, rising to 1.7 to 2.0 percent in 2016.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Let me now return to our decision to make another measured reduction in the pace of asset purchases.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Starting next month, we will be purchasing $55 billion of securities per month, down $10 billion per month from our current rate.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Even after today’s action takes effect, we will continue to significantly expand our holdings of longer-term securities, and we will also continue to roll over maturing Treasury securities and reinvest principal payments from the FOMC’s holdings of agency debt and agency mortgage-backed securities in agency mortgage-backed securities.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: These sizable and still-increasing holdings will continue to put downward pressure on longer-term interest rates, support mortgage markets, and make financial conditions more accommodative, helping to support job creation and a return of inflation to the Committee’s objective.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: The FOMC views today’s decision to reduce the pace of asset purchases as consistent with the decisionmaking framework laid out last December and still in place today.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: As before, if incoming information broadly supports the Committee’s expectation of ongoing improvement in labor markets and inflation moving back over time toward its longer-run objective, the Committee will likely continue to reduce the pace of asset purchases in measured steps at future meetings.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: However, purchases are not on a preset course, and the Committee’s decisions about the pace of purchases remain contingent on its outlook for jobs and inflation as well as its assessment of the likely efficacy and costs of such purchases.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Today the FOMC also updated its forward guidance regarding the path of short-term interest rates.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: As emphasized in the statement, the new guidance does not indicate any change in  explain this more fully.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: In December 2012, the Committee first stated its guidance in terms of economic thresholds, stipulating that the current low range for the federal funds rate target would be appropriate at least as long as the unemployment rate remains above 6½ percent, inflation is projected to be no more than a half percentage point above our longer-run goal, and longer-term inflation expectations remain well anchored.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Since that time, progress in the labor market has been more rapid than we had anticipated, while inflation has been lower than the Committee had expected.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Although the thresholds served well as a useful guide to policy over the past year, last December the FOMC judged it appropriate to update that guidance, noting that the current target range for the federal funds rate would likely be maintained “well past the time that the unemployment rate declines below 6½ percent, especially if projected inflation continues to run below the Committee’s 2 percent longer-run goal.” Today the Committee has further revised its forward guidance to better reflect conditions as they now stand and are likely to evolve over coming quarters.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: The revised formulation starts with a general description of the factors that drive FOMC decisionmaking and then provides the FOMC’s current assessment of what those factors will likely imply for the future path of short-term interest rates.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: In particular, the Committee states that “[i]n determining how long to maintain the current 0 to ¼ percent target range for the federal funds rate, it [the Committee] will assess progress—both realized and expected—toward its objectives of maximum employment and 2 percent inflation.”  In short, the larger the shortfall of employment or inflation from the respective objectives set by the FOMC, and the longer any such shortfall is expected to persist, the longer the target federal funds rate is likely to remain in the present 0 to ¼ percent range.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: of labor market conditions, indicators of inflation pressures and inflation expectations, and readings on financial developments.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: As I’ve noted, the FOMC’s assessment of these factors at present is consistent with the characterization provided in previous forward guidance.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: The Committee continues to anticipate that conditions will likely warrant maintaining “the current range for the federal funds rate for a considerable time after the asset purchase program ends, especially if projected inflation continues to run below the Committee’s 2 percent longer-run goal, and provided that longer-term inflation expectations remain well anchored.” The FOMC also supplemented its guidance pertaining to the period after the asset purchase program ends and the initial increase in the federal funds rate target has occurred.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: The statement continues to note that in deciding on the pace for removing accommodation, the Committee will take a balanced approach to attaining its objectives.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: The statement now adds the Committee’s current anticipation that “even after employment and inflation are near mandate-consistent levels, economic conditions may, for some time, warrant keeping” short-term interest rates “below levels the Committee views as normal in the longer run.”  This guidance is consistent with the paths for appropriate policy as reported in the participants’ projections, which show the federal funds rate for most participants remaining well below longer-run normal values at the end of 2016.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Although FOMC participants provide a number of explanations for the federal funds rate target remaining below its longer-run normal level, many cite the residual impacts of the financial crisis, and some note that the potential growth rate of the economy may be lower, at least for a time.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: labor market is continuing, but that much remains to be done on both the jobs and inflation fronts.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Unemployment is still elevated, underemployment and long-term unemployment remain significant concerns, and inflation is running significantly below the FOMC’s objective.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: These conditions warrant the continuation of highly accommodative policy reflected in today’s policy statement.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: The Federal Reserve’s interest rate guidance and its substantial and still-increasing holdings of longer-term securities will ensure that monetary policy remains highly accommodative, promoting the FOMC’s objectives of maximum employment and price stability.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: I’ll be glad to take your questions.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: So, I—you know, this is the kind of term—it’s hard to define.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: But, you know, it probably means something on the order of around six months or that type of thing.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: But, you know, it depends.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: What the statement is saying is, it depends what conditions are like.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: We need to see where the labor market is, how close are we to our full employment goal—that will be a  toward it?
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Are we really close and moving fast?
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Or are we getting closer but moving very slowly?
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: And then, what the statement emphasizes, and this is the same language we used in December and January, we used the language especially if inflation is running below our 2 percent objective.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Inflation matters here, too, and our general principle tries to capture that notion.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: If we have a substantial shortfall in inflation, if inflation is persistently running below our 2 percent objective, that is a very good reason to hold the funds rate at its present range for longer.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: The Committee’s Vice Chairman, Bill Dudley, said recently, “If the economy decided it was going to grow at 5 percent or the economy decided it wasn’t going to grow at all, those would be the kind of changes in the outlook that I think would warrant changing the pace of taper[ing].”  Is that an accurate description of what you mean when you say that you’re not on a preset course, anything between zero to five?
Speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

Sentences: And, secondly, if I may, there’s a lot of research showing that short-term unemployment seems to be responsible for the level of inflation and that long-term unemployment seems relatively uncorrelated.
Speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

Sentences: Is that the Fed’s view at this point?
Speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

Sentences: Is that one reason that you expect inflation to rebound in the next couple of years?
Speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

Sentences: So I think the numbers you cited would be extremes in terms of defining what we’d need to see.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: I wouldn’t go to such extremes.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: I guess the way I would put it is this:  There are two conditions for the Committee to decide to continue tapering the pace of purchases.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: The first is that we need to assess that the labor market continues to be on the mend and that we feel reasonably satisfied that the outlook is for further improvement in the labor market that will get us back to our maximum employment objective.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: And, second of all, we  well below our objective.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: And we need to see evidence that leaves us feeling satisfied that inflation will move up over time, that we believe the evidence is consistent with its moving up over time.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: If the Committee no longer feels comfortable making such assessments—so, if there is enough change in the data we’re seeing about the economy that it no longer seems reasonable or convincing to make those two separate assessments, then a case has been made to change the pace of asset purchases and to deviate from the current plan.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: So 5 percent and 1 percent, those are very extreme numbers.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: But I would want to feel confident in making those two statements about the labor market and inflation.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: With respect to the issue of short-term unemployment and its being more relevant for inflation and a better measure of the labor market, I’ve seen research along those lines.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: I think it would be tremendously premature to adopt any notion that says that that is an accurate read on either how inflation is determined or what constitutes slack in the labor market.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: So I think this is something our Committee will be looking at, especially as unemployment goes down and other labor market indicators hopefully simultaneously improve.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: We’ll be looking at a broad range of indicators.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: We’re looking to see progress on many different dimensions where we see slack in the economy, but I wouldn’t endorse, and I certainly don’t think our Committee would endorse, the judgment of the research that you cited.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Jeff Kearns from Bloomberg News.
Speaker: JEFF KEARNS.

Sentences: You’ve spoken in the past about—thinking about back to March of last year—of how you supplement your view of the labor market beyond unemployment with other gauges like quit rates and layoffs and things like that.
Speaker: JEFF KEARNS.

Sentences: How has your dashboard evolved in the past few months in terms both of the—which indicators  positive, negative—that you’re getting from these indicators.
Speaker: JEFF KEARNS.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: JEFF KEARNS.

Sentences: So I have talked in the past about indicators I like to watch or I think that are relevant in assessing the labor market.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: In addition to the standard unemployment rate, I certainly look at broader measures of unemployment.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: I mentioned U-6 in my statement.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: It—5 percent of the labor force working part time on an involuntary basis, that’s an exceptionally high number relative to the measured unemployment rate, and it—so, to my mind, is a form of slack that is—adds to what we see in the normal unemployment rate and is unusually large.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: However, it is coming down, as well as U-3.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: It’s moving in the right direction and has moved even more recently than U-3.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Of course, I watch discouraged and marginally attached workers.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: The share of long-term unemployment has been immensely high and can be very stubborn in bringing down, that’s something that I watch closely.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Again, that remains exceptionally high, but it has come down from something like 45 percent to high 30s, but that’s certainly on my dashboard.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Labor force participation—I do think most research suggests that due to demographic factors, labor force participation will be coming down, and there has been a downward trend now for a number of years.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: But I think there is also a cyclical component in the fact that labor force participation is depressed.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: And so, it may be that as the economy begins to strengthen, we could see labor force participation flatten out for a time as discouraged workers start moving back into the labor market.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: And so that’s something I’m watching closely.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: In the Committee, we’ll have to watch—there are different views on this within the Committee, and it’s hard to know definitively what part of labor force participation is structural versus cyclical, so it’s something to watch closely.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: I’ve also mentioned, in the past, measures of labor market turnover.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: You mentioned quits.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: A remarkably large share of workers quit their  as a sign of the health of the economy.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: When workers are scared they won’t be able to get other jobs, they show a reduced willingness to quit their jobs.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Now, quit rates now are below normal pre-recession levels, but on the other hand, they have come up over time, and so we have seen improvement.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: The job opening rate has also come up.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: The hires rate, however, remains extremely depressed, and I take that as a sign of a weaker labor market.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: But most of these measures, although they don’t paint the identical extent of improvement, if you ask about my dashboard, the dial on virtually all of those things is moving in a direction of improvement.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: The final thing I’d mention is wages, and wage growth has really been very low.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: I know there is perhaps one isolated measure of wage growth that suggests some uptick, but most measures of wage increase are running at very low levels.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: In fact, with the productivity growth we have and 2 percent inflation, one would probably expect to see, on an ongoing basis, something between—perhaps 3 and 4 percent wage inflation would be normal.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Wage inflation has been running at 2 percent.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: So not only is it depressed, signaling weakness in the labor market, but it is certainly not flashing.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: An increase in it might signal some tightening or meaningful pressures on inflation, at least over time.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: And I would say we’re not seeing that.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Madam Chair, Wyatt Andrews from CBS.
Speaker: WYATT ANDREWS.

Sentences: For tens of millions of Americans, the recovery is an awful long time coming.
Speaker: WYATT ANDREWS.

Sentences: May we know your thoughts on why the recovery is so slow, and why the economy is not creating more jobs?
Speaker: WYATT ANDREWS.

Sentences: Well, I think the short answer is that we have lived through a devastating financial crisis that has taken an exceptional toll on the economy in many different ways, from housing to leaving a huge number of homeowners with mortgages living in homes with mortgages that are underwater, has had a highly negative effect on their credit ratings and  business investment spending that is very restrained.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: On top of that, we’ve had weakness in the global economy, and we’ve had a very tight fiscal policy at home.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: After stimulus at the onset of the recession, we’ve had a good deal of fiscal consolidation in the United States and, at a time when fiscal policy normally in the past would have been serving to create jobs, fiscal policy from that standpoint has served as a headwind to the recovery.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: And at the federal—especially at the federal level, but also with state and local levels as well.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: And so we have had a disappointing recovery.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: And monetary policy has tried to do what we can to offset that.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: But, you know, the linkages aren’t as strong and aren’t as quick as we might ideally like them to be.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: GREG ROBB.

Sentences: I’d like to take you back to last summer when there were hints—the Fed made hints that they were going to taper, and long-term interest rates spiked, mortgage rates rose.
Speaker: GREG ROBB.

Sentences: What lessons—looking back at that crisis, at that period, what lessons have you learned from it, and are you confident that you won’t repeat that—those mistakes again?
Speaker: GREG ROBB.

Sentences: Well, I think there were quite a number of things happening at that time.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: I think it’s probably true that monetary policy may have played a role in touching off that market reaction, but I think the market reaction was exacerbated by the fact that we had a very significant unwinding of carry trades and other leveraged positions that investors had taken, perhaps thinking that the level of volatility was exceptionally low and perhaps lower than was safe for them to have assumed.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: But we certainly saw—now, in some ways, the fact that term premia in interest rates have come up somewhat, although it has had a negative effect on the recovery and that’s evident in housing—in the slowdown in housing—perhaps it’s diminished some financial instability risk that may have been associated with these carry trades and speculative activities that were unwinding during that time.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: A lesson is that we will try, and we  how we will conduct monetary policy and to be as steady and determined and as transparent as we can to provide as much clarity as is reasonably certain—given that the economic developments in the economy are themselves uncertain—but we will try as hard as we can not to be a source of instability here.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Madam Chair, Rebecca Jarvis, ABC News.
Speaker: REBECCA JARVIS.

Sentences: One of the drivers last spring and summer of home prices and home sales was that sense that interest rates were going up, that they were spiking.
Speaker: REBECCA JARVIS.

Sentences: And now, a year later, we’re looking essentially at a flat interest rate picture as far as homebuyers are concerned.
Speaker: REBECCA JARVIS.

Sentences: So, is there any sense on your Committee that staying at this level loses its punch the longer we remain here?
Speaker: REBECCA JARVIS.

Sentences: And if I’m a buyer, and I’m thinking about going out and buying a home, why should I do that today as opposed to waiting a few more years or even months before interest rates then do go up?
Speaker: REBECCA JARVIS.

Sentences: Well, I think the level of interest rates remains low by historic levels.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: And the level of household formation is very depressed, has been very depressed for some time.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: There are a lot of kids who were shacking up with their families and probably would like to be going out and acquiring places of their own, whether it’s an apartment or a home.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: There’s a lot of demographic potential there for new household formation that would ultimately generate new construction, either single or multifamily, and the level of rates I think does matter.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: And the fact that they’re low now, I think, is something that should serve as a stimulus to people coming back into the housing market.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: And what we’ve not yet seen—the pickup after the lull—after interest rates went up last summer, I do expect housing activity to begin to expand more rapidly later on.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: I don’t think it’s only the expectation that “I have to move now or things will be more expensive later” that spurs those decisions.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: So—  fact that you and your predecessor agreed on many policies.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: You shared a lot of the same policy views.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Can you tell us one way in which your chairmanship will be different than Ben Bernanke’s?
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Well, I think we are committed to exactly the same set of goals.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: And, you know, as I indicated, I—my goal, and I will, you know, throw myself into this as wholeheartedly as I can, is to make rapid progress, as rapid progress as we possibly can in getting this recovery back on track and putting Americans back to work and into jobs, and in moving inflation back up to levels at the Committee’s target of 2 percent.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: My predecessor was also devoted to that.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Strengthening the financial system is a work in progress, and he made large inroads in strengthening the financial system.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: I’d just say, there is more work to be done, I have a long to-do list.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: I would absolutely—it’s high priority for me to see further work done in addressing too-big-to-fail.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: We have a to-do list of things we want to accomplish, and in assessing threats to financial stability because neither one of us—and no one wants to live through a financial crisis like the last one, and we want to be extremely cognizant of emerging threats to the financial system.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: So I haven’t answered your question by saying that I will be different, but I think he had a very good agenda, and it’s one I shared.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: It’s why I came to Washington to be Vice Chair, and it’s the agenda I expect to continue pursuing.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Madam Chair, Peter Barnes of Fox Business.
Speaker: PETER BARNES.

Sentences: I wanted to talk about international developments and the crisis in the Ukraine.
Speaker: PETER BARNES.

Sentences: Is the crisis a headwind for the U.S. economy?
Speaker: PETER BARNES.

Sentences: Are there risks to the U.S. economy and the U.S. banking system, directly and indirectly?
Speaker: PETER BARNES.

Sentences: And did the Russians move $100 billion in U.S. Treasury securities out of the United  are held by the Fed.
Speaker: PETER BARNES.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: PETER BARNES.

Sentences: So let me start with the last piece of your question first.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: I’m sorry, I—movements in custodial accounts at the New York Fed are something that I can’t—I’m not in the position to be able to comment about.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: But in terms of the situation in Ukraine and Russia, it’s something that we’re monitoring very closely.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: We discussed in our meeting the direct-trade linkages or exposures of the U.S. banking system to the Ukraine and Russia are not large.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: That’s—we’re not seeing meaningful impacts now, but obviously there are geopolitical risks here that it’s very important for us to be attentive to and to keep our eye on.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: And we’re not seeing broader global financial repercussions, but if this were to escalate, that would certainly be something that would be on our radar screen, but we’re not seeing—we’re not seeing that now and we’re monitoring it closely.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: Victoria McGrane from Dow Jones Newswires.
Speaker: VICTORIA MCGRANE.

Sentences: You’ve spoken about how unemployment is more than just statistics to you.
Speaker: VICTORIA MCGRANE.

Sentences: And I wanted to ask, when you make that statement, who do you have in mind or—and what do you do, if anything, to keep in touch with that kind of human side of the impact of the economic crisis and slow recovery that we’ve had?
Speaker: VICTORIA MCGRANE.

Sentences: Well, I’d be surprised if anyone in this room doesn’t know someone who has been touched by the crisis, by unemployment, by difficulties in getting jobs, and that is true of me and my family and friends, I think, as it is probably for many of you.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: I talk to a broad range of business contacts and try to stay in touch with what’s happening with real people in the economy.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: We have—do a lot of work in community development in the Fed and have groups come to talk to us and explain to us how their communities have been affected by the economic  had programs there, we worked very closely, particularly in low-income communities that have been very badly affected, to design programs that could potentially be helpful.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: We tried to study what kinds of programs can be most effective and to try to understand what kinds of advice we could give to those in the community development lending field to help.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentences: So I do try to listen to people that represent communities that are experiencing the worst of the crisis and stay in touch with it that way.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.
